instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2915: What is 820-2915? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_CPU: What is PPVCORE_S0_CPU? This is the primary power rail for the CPU that powers the CPU, known as CPU vcore. Without this, the machine will be braindead. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no CPU VCORE
threads.message:
No corrosion.

Power rails all present and correct aside from:

<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PPVCCSA_S0_REG</SIGNAL> = 0.98 (not sure about this one)

Checked <CHIP>U7400</CHIP>
Pin 1, <SIGNAL>CPU_IMVP_VR_ON</SIGNAL>  = 3V3
Pin 2, <SIGNAL>CPUIMVP_TON</SIGNAL> = 12V5
Pin 15, 24,  <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> = 5V

No idea where to go from here.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no CPU VCORE
threads.message: This is going to suck. Try a donor BIOS and inspect board for physical damage. Also heat the GPU first to eliminate that.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no CPU VCORE
threads.message:
Tried GPU but no go.
Tried replacing <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> because it's not putting anything out to FET gates.
SPIROM is good.

Guess I'll check current sensing and look deeper into what's going on around <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> circuits.

Any other ideas?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no CPU VCORE
threads.message: Nooooo, <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> is fine. <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> needs communication with CPU to turn it on. This could really be anything. Check damaged components, was it dropped? Did you really try BIOS? Again this board will probably be a rabbit hole...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no CPU VCORE
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 17202"]Nooooo, <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> is fine. <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> needs communication with CPU to turn it on. This could really be anything. Check damaged components, was it dropped? Did you really try BIOS? Again this board will probably be a rabbit hole...[/QUOTE]

Had to test ROM in the TL866 as no donor chips with correct BIOS here. Reads good 3 times with same checksum so I guess it's OK since it reads. Checked the reads in UEFI tool too.

Everything I get from this guy recently is either a clean shiny rabbit hole or a corroded crusty asshole resulting in wasted time. I can't see that it's been dropped but who fucking knows man.... It's going back dead.
My time is worth more than figuring out this problem.

Appreciate the help Duke, thank you.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no CPU VCORE
threads.message: Uhm, if the chip was corrupted how would reading it 3 times confirm it is good? Flash it with a known good file and see if it works.....

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no CPU VCORE
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 17253"]Uhm, if the chip was corrupted how would reading it 3 times confirm it is good? Flash it with a known good file and see if it works.....[/QUOTE]

OK that's a good point, I was only testing if the chip itself was working. I'll try that first.... Do you have good EFI?
